column1: Dumont has two major parks in the borough.  Memorial Park is located on the east side of Dumont.  It is made up of five ball parks
column3: a basketball court
column4: and a pavilion.  The park is used throughout the year mostly for Little League and Dumont High School Baseball.  During the summer Memorial Park is used for the Dumont Summer Recreation Program.  The other park in Dumont is Twin Boro Field
column5: located on the opposite side of the borough.  Twin Boro is a huge field which is used for recreational football and soccer.  There is also a softball field that is used for the Dumont Men's Softball League.  Right next to Twin Boro is Gina's Field which consists of two girls softball fields and a playground.  To the right of Twin Boro Field is the Dumont Swim Club.  The Swim Club's parking lot doubles as a roller hockey rink for Dumont's Hockey League.  Memorial Park and Twin Boro Fields are two of the largest parks in Dumont.Dumont recreational sports consist of Dumont Little League

column1: Dumont is governed under the Borough form of New Jersey municipal government
column2: which is used in 218 (of the 565) municipalities statewide
column3: making it the most common form of government in New Jersey. The governing body is comprised of a Mayor and a Borough Council
column4: with all positions elected at-large on a partisan basis as part of the November general election. A Mayor is elected directly by the voters to a four-year term of office. The Borough Council is comprised of six members elected to serve three-year terms on a staggered basis
column5: with two seats coming up for election each year in a three-year cycle. The Borough form of government used by Dumont is a "weak mayor / strong council" government in which council members act as the legislative body with the mayor presiding at meetings and voting only in the event of a tie. The mayor can veto ordinances subject to an override by a two-thirds majority vote of the council. The mayor makes committee and liaison assignments for council members
column6: and most appointments are made by the mayor with the advice and consent of the council.As of 2020
column7: the Mayor of the Borough of Dumont is Democrat Andrew LaBruno
column8: whose term of office ends December 31

column22: when she won election to serve the balance of the term of office.In February 2017

column1: The Dumont Police Department operates out of the Borough Hall and protect and serves the community around the clock. The police department also includes volunteer reserve officers. The department's Chief of Police is Michael J. Conner.The Fire Department is manned by approximately 80 volunteer firefighters located at four different fire houses throughout the borough. Christian Baierwalter of Engine/Rescue Company 3 is Chief of the Department
column2: Mark Abdulla of Independent Hose Company is Assistant Chief
column3: and Paul Pfeiffer of Truck Company 2 is Deputy Chief. The Dumont Fire Department responds to about 325 calls per year
column4: including mutual aid to neighboring municipalities including Tenafly
column10: and the Northern Valley towns when needed. The Dumont Fire Department is equipped with eight pieces of apparatus (four engines

column1: The Dumont Public Schools serve students in pre-kindergarten through twelfth grade. As of the 2018–19 school year
column3: comprised of five schools
column5: 538 students and 211.1 classroom teachers (on an FTE basis)
column6: for a student–teacher ratio of 12.0:1. Schools in the district (with 2018–19 enrollment data from the National Center for Education Statistics) are

column1: Grant School with 384 students in grades K-5 (opened 1911)
Honiss School with 610 students in grades K-8 (opened 1955)
Lincoln School with 150 students in grades K-5 (opened 1911)
Selzer School with 527 students in grades PreK-8 (opened 1960) and
Dumont High School with 802 students in grades 9-12 (opened 1932).Public school students from the borough
column3: are eligible to attend the secondary education programs offered by the Bergen County Technical Schools
column4: which include the Bergen County Academies in Hackensack
column5: and the Bergen Tech campus in Teterboro or Paramus. The district offers programs on a shared-time or full-time basis
column6: with admission based on a selective application process and tuition covered by the student's home school district.Newbury Academy is a private alternative high school for students in grades 9-12 that was founded in Teaneck in 2001 and moved to Dumont in 2003. As of September 2008
column7: Newbury Academy has become a virtual school with all classes being conducted online
column8: with teachers making weekly visits to students' homes.

column2: the borough had a total of 47.96 miles (77.18 km) of roadways
column3: of which 43.38 miles (69.81 km) were maintained by the municipality and 4.58 miles (7.37 km) by Bergen County.The most significant road directly serving Dumont is County Route 505
column4: which follows Knickerbocker Road along the right border of the borough. Other main roads in Dumont include Madison Avenue and Washington Avenue.

column1: The NJ Transit 166 and 167 bus routes provides service between the borough and the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Midtown Manhattan; the 186 serves the George Washington Bridge Bus Terminal; and local service is available on the 753 and 772 routes.
